items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Media Capture and Streams Extensions, section MediaStreamTrack Statistics and specifically the MediaStreamTrackAudioStats subsection.
  • Specification or proposal URL: https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-extensions/#dom-mediastreamtrackaudiostats
  • Proposal author(s): @henbos
  • Mozillians who can provide input: @padenot @jan-ivar

This request related to the track.stats API for when MediaStreamTrack is an audio track sourced from getUserMedia. The API shape is the same as for video (previous standards-position: #895) but audio tracks has a separate interface defined for the metrics since these definitions are specific to audio: MediaStreamTrackAudioStats.

The motivation for this API is to monitor quality, on an individual basis, e.g. a user of a web app is experiencing quality issues, which part of the pipeline is responsible or is it caused by the device needs to be debugged using metrics from the wild specific to that app and user, and for A/B testing, for example understanding how rolling out features in video conferencing web app affect the quality of the users of that web app. The latency metric may additionally be used by a web app as input for example to WebAudio which may aid audio processing use cases, but this is also useful as a quality indicator too.

So there are two types of metrics exposed by this API:

  1. Audio frame counters and duration, including frames delivered and total frames. This allows calculating dropped frames (or frames duration) as "dropped = total - delivered". This allows estimating glitches, such device connectivity issues (e.g. poor bluetooth connection), the OS or user agent is dropping frames or other device issues. It is important to have this in JS because issues like this typically happen in the wild rather than in lab conditions.
  2. Microphone input latency. This is always useful and I believe @padenot has said that web developers have been asking for this for years? At the time of writing latency has been merged into the spec but the PR that adds min/max/avg latency is still in review: w3c/mediacapture-extensions#134 (Update: the resolution from last meeting is to adopt the PR).

Mozilla has expressed interest in latency but has opposed measuring audio drops, see below for history and more information.

Other information

  • The dropped frames disagreement was discussed in the September WebRTC WG meeting (link with timestamp) where no consensus was reached.
  • w3c/mediacapture-extensions#129 is the issue for the disagreement, which adds some information to the discussion, including how device connectivity can cause glitches before audio reaches the UA. This issue is still open.
  • The blink-dev Intent to Prototype shows support from GoTo, Teams and Zoom.
items.title: MediaStreamTrack Statistics (Audio)

Other information

Navigation Activation exposes information about the most recent cross-document navigation (aka "activation").
It exposes the old URL, new URL, and navigation type.
This is mainly useful for cross-document view transitions.

Navigation Activation is namespaced to the navigation API and uses the NavigationHistoryEntry interface, but other than that it's a somewhat self-contained.

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Opener Storage Partitioning
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://arichiv.github.io/opener-storage-partitioning/
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @arichiv @johannhof
  • Bug Tracker URL (optional): https://crbug.com/1159586
  • WebKit Position: WebKit/standards-positions#277
  • Tag Position: w3ctag/design-reviews#916

Other information

Our goal is to maintain cross-page communication where important to web function while striking a better balance with user-privacy.

This will be done in two steps. First, whenever a frame navigates cross-origin any other windows with a window.opener handle pointing to the navigating frame will have that handle cleared. Second, either (a) any frames with a valid window.opener (or window.top.opener) handle at the time of navigation will have transient storage via a StorageKey nonce instead of access to standard first- and third-party StorageKeys or (b) the opener will be severed by default until user interaction or an API call restores it.

The first proposal should be less disruptive than either of the second, but metrics will need to be gathered on both. Once implemented, these proposals together prevent any synchronous or asynchronous communication between a first- and third-party storage bucket for the same origin. Instead, communication between two buckets for the same origin will only be possible if one of the buckets is transient. This mitigates the threats we are concerned with.
items.title: Opener Protections

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: PNG, section 11.3.2.6 cICP Coding-independent code points
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://w3c.github.io/PNG-spec/#cICP-chunk
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/w3c/PNG-spec/blob/main/Third_Edition_Explainer.md#labelling-hdr-content
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): PNG WG
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional): https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1862245
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional):

Other information

CICP is a way to identify the color space and transfer function; specified in ITU-T-H.273 originally for video formats, it is now widely deployed and starting to be used in image formats such as AVIF and JPEG-XL. It is particularly used for HDR content, but can also be used for SDR content. Compared to an embedded ICC profile, which can be 10-20k for an RGB colorspace, it only adds 4 bytes of data because it is an enumeration.

For example, an image in BT.2100 color space with the PQ transfer function would signal this with the following four bytes:

9 16 0 1

while an image in Display P3 would use

11 13 0 1

Gecko already supports CICP in AVIF, see https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1634741

The need for PNG to support HDR images was identified at the W3C Color Workshop and incubated in the Color on the Web CG

PNG Third Edition adds the cICP chunk for CICP, and this is already supported in Chrome. It is produced by image editing applications including darktable and Adobe Photoshop.
items.title: Coding Independent Code Points (CICP) and PNG `cICP`

Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Add a close event to MessagePort
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available):
  • Explainer URL (if available):https://github.com/fergald/explainer-messageport-close
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @fergald @nononokam
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional): @asutherland

Other information

Currently, there is no timely and reliable way to detect when a MessagePort becomes disentangled, which makes it difficult to release resources associated with ports. This issue has a long discussion of the problem and potential solutions. Some users have used the unload event to detect disconnect, but it is deprecated. Therefore, The approach available now is to hold a MessagePort in WeakRef and periodically check if this port has been garbage collected by using deref() or to make use of a page-hide event, which is quite inefficient.
So, I propose adding a close event. For example, if there are two entangled ports, portA and portB, and portA is closed, the close event is fired on portB.
items.title: Add a close event to MessagePort

Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Device Bound Session Credentials
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available):
  • Explainer URL (if available): https://github.com/WICG/dbsc/blob/main/README.md
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @kristianmonsen
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional):

Other information

In their words "Device Bound Session Credentials (DBSC) aims to reduce account hijacking caused by cookie theft. It does so by introducing a protocol and browser infrastructure to maintain and prove possession of a cryptographic key. The main challenge with cookies as an authentication mechanism is that they only lend themselves to bearer-token schemes. On desktop operating systems, application isolation is lacking and local malware can generally access anything that the browser itself can, and the browser must be able to access cookies. On the other hand, authentication with a private key allows for the use of system-level protection against key exfiltration."
items.title: Device Bound Session Credentials
